definition:
Let $X = \prod_{i \in I} X_i$ be a Cartesian product. Call two elements
$x,y \in X$ *almost equal* if the set
$\Delta(x,y) = \{i \in I \mid x_i \neq y_i\}$ is finite. A function
$f : X \to X$ is said to be *pre-injective* if it sends distinct almost
equal elements into distinct elements, [*i.e.*]{}, if
$0 < |\Delta(x,y)| < \infty$ implies $f(x) \not= f(y)$.

If $X$ is finite, pre-injectivity is the same as injectivity; in
general, the latter implies the former, but not the other way around.
Moreover, it is not true in general that a composition of pre-injective
functions is itself pre-injective.

A cellular automaton is said to be pre-injective if its global function
is. As cellular automata send almost equal configurations into almost
equal configurations, the composition of two pre-injective cellular
automata is pre-injective.

Pre-injectivity of cellular automata can be characterized via mutually
erasable patterns. Given a finite subset $E$ of $G$, two patterns
$p_1,p_2 : E \to Q$ are *mutually erasable* (briefly, m.e.) for a
cellular automaton $\Acal = \langle Q, \Neigh, f \rangle$ on $G$ if for
any two configurations $c_1,c_2 : G \to Q$ such that
$\restrict{c_i}{E} = p_i$ and
$\restrict{c_1}{G \setminus E} = \restrict{c_2}{G \setminus E}$ one has
$F_{\ensuremath{\mathcal{A}}}(c_1) = F_{\ensuremath{\mathcal{A}}}(c_2)$.

\[lem:me\] For a cellular automaton
$\Acal = \langle Q, \Neigh, f \rangle,$ the following are equivalent.

1.  \[it:me\] ${\ensuremath{\mathcal{A}}}$ has no mutually erasable
    patterns.

2.  \[it:ea\] ${\ensuremath{\mathcal{A}}}$ is pre-injective.

*Proof.* It is immediate that the negation of point \[it:me\] implies
the negation of point \[it:ea\]. So let $c_1,c_2 : G \to Q$ be two
distinct almost equal configurations such that
$F_\Acal(c_1) = F_\Acal(c_2):$ it is not restrictive to suppose that
${\ensuremath{\mathcal{N}}}$ is symmetric ([*i.e.*]{}, if
$x \in {\ensuremath{\mathcal{N}}}$ then
$x^{-1} \in {\ensuremath{\mathcal{N}}}$) and $e$, the identity element
of $G$, belongs to ${\ensuremath{\mathcal{N}}}$. Let $\Delta$ be a
finite subset of $G$ such that
$\restrict{c_1}{G \setminus \Delta} = \restrict{c_2}{G \setminus \Delta},$
and let $$E = \Delta {\ensuremath{\mathcal{N}}}^2
  = \{ g \in G
       \mid \exists z \in \Delta, u,v \in {\ensuremath{\mathcal{N}}}\mid g = zuv
    \} \;:$$ we shall prove that $p_1 = \restrict{c_1}{E}$ and
$p_2 = \restrict{c_2}{E}$ are mutually erasable. (They surely are
distinct, since $\Delta \subseteq E$.)

So let $\gamma_1,\gamma_2 : G \to Q$ satisfy
$\restrict{\gamma_i}{E} = p_i$ and
$\restrict{\gamma_2}{G \setminus E} = p_i = \restrict{\gamma_2}{G \setminus E}.$
Let $z \in G$. If $z \in \Delta{\ensuremath{\mathcal{N}}}$, then
$F_{\ensuremath{\mathcal{A}}}(\gamma_1)(z) = F_{\ensuremath{\mathcal{A}}}(\gamma_2)(z)$,
because by construction
$\restrict{\gamma_i}{z\Neigh} = \restrict{c_i}{z\Neigh};$ if
$z \in G \setminus \Delta\Neigh,$ then
$F_{\ensuremath{\mathcal{A}}}(\gamma_1)(z) = F_{\ensuremath{\mathcal{A}}}(\gamma_2)(z)$
as well, because by construction
$\restrict{\gamma_1}{z\Neigh} = \restrict{\gamma_2}{z\Neigh}.$ Since
$\gamma_1$ and $\gamma_2$ are arbitrary, $p_1$ and $p_2$ are mutually
erasable. $\Box$
